name: Italian Burl Wood Lighter Cases
details: Radica lighter cases, Italian, 1970s. Pair of 7cm H each. Handcrafted burl wood with natural figuring. Metal fittings with aged patina. The kind of pocket luxury that made smoking an art form.

name: Silver & Mother-of-Pearl Lighter Case
details: Sterling silver with inlaid mother-of-pearl geometric pattern. Art Deco influence—clean lines, luxury materials, precision inlay. Aged patina. 7cm H. A piece that bridges function and jewelry.

name: Italian Marquetry Box
details: Burl wood with lighter wood inlay, Italian, early 20th century. Intarsia work forming scrolling patterns on figured wood. 3.2cm H x 13cm W x 9cm D. Cigarette or small valuables box.

name: Attributed Carlo Bugatti Chairs
details: Set of 7 chairs attributed to Carlo Bugatti. Parchment and bronze/brass, Italian. Exotic materials, geometric patterns, theatrical construction. Vellum stretched over wooden frames, brass or bronze hardware. Attribution based on style and construction. No maker's marks visible. Parchment shows age and honest wear. Rare to find seven together in original condition.

name: Iron Knife Rests
details: Medieval-inspired creatures—griffins, dragons, chimeras. Hand-forged iron with decorative detailing. Gothic Revival romanticized the medieval. Hand-forged iron, dark patina. 7cm W each.

name: Art Deco Ceramic Wall Sconces
details: Ceramic with cream glaze, Belgian, 1930s-40s. Half-moon uplighters with vertical ribbing. Classic Deco geometry—theaters, hotel lobbies, ocean liners. Wired and functional. 16cm H each.

name: Wrought Iron Candelabra
details: Wrought iron, French, 19th/early 20th century. Gothic Revival style. Multiple candle holders on architectural frames. Hand-forged construction. Heavy. Dark patina. Pair.

name: Greek Style Amphora Vase
details: Black-figure style, 19th century. Greek or Italian souvenir. Tourist copies made for Grand Tour travelers. Terracotta, black glaze. 32cm H. The kind of piece that made the journey home in steamer trunks.

name: Greek Miniature Vases
details: Black-figure style, 19th century. Greek or Italian souvenirs. Five variations—kraters, amphorae, different mythological scenes. Tourist copies made for Grand Tour travelers. Together they're a collection, not just souvenirs. Terracotta, black glaze. 10-14cm H each.

name: Neoclassical Ceramic Vase
details: Black ceramic with classical relief decoration. Mid-century neoclassicism—ancient forms with modern materials. Twin handles, Roman scene in relief. Wedgwood influence filtered through Mediterranean craft tradition. Black glazed ceramic, relief decoration. 20cm H x 17cm Diameter.

name: Etched Glass Decanters
details: Hand-cut crystal, Italian, late 19th/early 20th century. Bulbous form with etched decorative bands. Sideboard pieces from formal dining rooms. Hand-cut pattern shows irregularity. 25cm H. Pair.

name: Art Deco Marble Candle Holders
details: Natural marble, Art Deco, 1920s-40s. Peach/cream marble with black base. Geometric columns—contrasting materials, sculptural quality. 16cm H each. Pair.

name: Targetti Sankey Spotlights
details: Italian industrial design, 1970s. Chrome and black enamel. Original labels intact. Targetti Sankey made architectural lighting for museums, galleries, offices. Functional Italian design—no ornament, pure utility elevated through proportion and material. Track-mounted, adjustable. Set of 6.

name: Large Pewter Urn
details: Italian, 19th/early 20th century Renaissance Revival. Heavy cast pewter, classical form with relief panels. The grey patina of pewter ages beautifully—darker than silver, warmer than steel. Cast pewter, natural patina. 35cm H.

name: White Stone & Brass Urn
details: White stone body, brass mounts with gilt finish. Neoclassical form—twin handles, pedestal base. The gilt is worn, showing age. Some collectors would regild it. Better to leave it as found. 28cm H.

name: Rococo Gilt Frames
details: Carved wood with gilt finish, Portuguese, 19th century. 32 x 28cm. Hand-carved scrollwork, acanthus leaves, baroque flourishes. Distressed gilding shows age and layers. Work empty or framed. Pair.

name: Danish Ebonized Frame
details: Carved wood, Danish or Northern European, mid-20th century. Geometric carved pattern—probably machine-carved rather than hand. Dark ebonized finish (stained black to mimic ebony). Large scale makes it architectural. 100cm x 54cm exterior, 78cm x 33cm interior.

name: Josef Hoffmann Fledermaus Chairs
details: Jacob & Josef Kohn manufacture, designed by Josef Hoffmann, 1904. Original stamps, original fabric, never restored. Vienna. Hoffmann founded the Wiener Werkstätte—bridge between Art Nouveau and Modernism. Designed for Cabaret Fledermaus in Vienna. Original condition with maker's stamps and distressed original upholstery. Collectors prefer honest age to restoration. Bentwood, original upholstery. Stamped. Pair.

name: Hoffmann Bentwood Chairs
details: Thonet manufacture, Josef Hoffmann design, circa 1900-1920s. Restored. Vienna. Classic Viennese café chairs—bentwood construction, simple lines, stackable design. These have been restored (refinished wood, new upholstery). Purists prefer original condition, but restored chairs are more functional. Bentwood, restored finish and upholstery. Set of 2.

name: Liberty Brass Lantern
details: Brass and glass, Italian Liberty (Art Nouveau) style, early 20th century. Pierced brass galleries with floral motifs, glass panels, hanging chains. Italian Liberty charming but quality metalwork. Brass with natural patina, glass panels. 41cm H x 27cm Diameter.

name: Iron & Sheepskin Benches
period: English Craft Design, Mid-20th Century, Pair
details: Wrought iron frames with sheepskin cushions, English craft design, mid-20th century or contemporary. Minimalist wrought iron, clean lines. Sculptural even without cushions. Works in modern or period spaces. Wrought iron, fake sheepskin. Pair.

name: Spanish Renaissance Frame
details: Carved wood, Spanish or Italian, late 19th/early 20th century. Deep relief carving—acanthus scrolls, floral corners, beaded border. Hand-carved, substantial wood. Dark stained finish. 60cm x 50cm Exterior, 38cm x 28cm Interior.

name: Janus Bust
details: White marble, Italian, 18th/19th century Grand Tour piece. Two-faced Roman god of transitions and doorways. Janus busts are rare. Exceptional detail in carved beards and hair. Natural aged patina. 24cm H.

name: Philosopher Head
details: Grey marble, 18th/19th century after the antique. Roman philosopher (198-217 AD). Grand Tour sculptors' inspiration. Short curly beard, heavy brow, characteristic scowl. Approximately 17cm H.

name: Burl Wood Art Deco Lamp
details: Belgian, Art Deco, 1930s-40s. Radica (burl wood) base, fabric shade. Geometric block form—pure Deco. Figured wood grain makes each piece unique. Belgian Art Deco had its own character—less ornate than French, more organic than German Bauhaus. Burl wood base, newer shade. Wired, functional. 55cm H x 46cm W x 36cm D.

name: Art Deco Door Handles
details: Bronze, French or Italian, 1930s-40s. Abstract organic forms. Sculptural hardware—leaf or flame motifs, Art Nouveau flowing into Deco geometry. Cast bronze with natural patina. Complete set of 5 (unusual—most survive in pairs or singles).

name: Spiral Cutlery Service
details: Silver-plated metal, French, mid-20th century. Spiral/twisted handle design. Complete service for 18. Art Moderne style—decorative but functional. Silver plate over base metal (not sterling). Shows age and use—some tarnish, wear to high points. Could be polished or left as is.

name: Bélier Ram's Head Case
details: French, late 19th/early 20th century. Silver plate over base metal. Novelty Edwardian box—ram's head form, hinged. These were made for jewelry, snuff, small valuables. Whimsical but quality—good casting detail, proper hinge mechanism. Silver plated metal, hinged. Aged patina.

name: Pewter Urns
details: Italian, 19th/early 20th century. Renaissance Revival style. Twin handled classical forms—one larger (28cm H), one smaller (24cm H). Cast pewter with relief decoration. The size variation makes them more interesting as a pair—asymmetry creates visual rhythm. Cast pewter, natural grey patina. Pair.

name: Flos Toio Lamp
details: Designed by Achille & Pier Giacomo Castiglioni, 1962. First series production. Icon of Italian Radical Design—car headlight, fishing rod, and steel base become a lamp. The Castiglioni brothers made anti-design design: industrial readymades elevated through wit and perfect proportion. MoMA permanent collection level. Original Flos production, working condition.

name: Metal Leaves & Grapes
details: Brass, Italian or French, mid-20th century. Grape bunches and leaves. Decorative objects cast metal with natural patina. The kind of thing that accumulates in European palazzos—too nice to throw away, too specific to know what to do with. Cast bronze/brass, patina. 19cm H. Set of 4.

name: Spanish Baroque Revival Mirror
details: Metal sheets heavily embossed, probably Spanish, 19th/early 20th century. Ornate carved crest. Heavy embossed metal—shell motif at top, geometric borders. Spanish Baroque loved drama—this mirror wants attention. Embossed metal, dark finish. Original mirror glass. 63cm H x 36cm W.

name: Italian Bentwood Chairs
details: Simple bentwood construction, Italian, mid-20th century. Honest construction, clean lines, functional. Not designer pieces but well-made everyday furniture. The kind that an architect would appreciate. Bentwood, natural finish. Set of 4.
